conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves upward, it becomes more directly overhead, affecting both the position and the size of the shadows.
As the light source moves upward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects casting them due to more vertical light rays.
The size of the shadows will decrease as the light source moves upward because the light rays are more parallel to each other when they reach the ground.
The shadow of Object A (Apple) will move closer to the apple and become smaller.
The shadow of Object B (Paper) will move closer to the paper and become smaller.
The shadow of Object C (Glass) will move closer to the glass and become smaller.
The shadow of Object D (Chicken Drumstick) will move closer to the drumstick and become smaller.
When the light source moves upward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will all move closer to their respective objects and decrease in size.
